PREVENTION PROGRAM DESCRIPTION

The Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center hazardous material release Prevention Program is built on the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard for ammonia refrigeration systems.  The first element in the safe function of ammonia refrigeration equipment is in the design itself.  All components of the systems were designed and installed in compliance with current IIAR, ANSI, ASHRAE and ASME standards.  In order for the system to function safely and effectively over a long period of time it must be properly maintained and monitored for system integrity and functional efficiency.  Maintenance and monitoring is accomplished by employees trained to follow safe procedures when operating the equipment from start up and shut down to normal operations and emergency shut down.  Also built into the system are manual and automatic safeguards that monitor and maintain pressures, temperatures, liquid levels and warning systems that alert operators to respond early to operational deviations before they become emergencies.  Both automatic and manual emergency shut down procedures and systems are designed and built into the system.

Operator training also includes participation in process hazard analysis studies and emergency response procedures that permit hands-on practice in the use of personal protective equipment in an emergency scenario.  The Process Hazard Analysis (what-if) study also helps operators and emergency responders understand how to evaluate and manage an emergency situation safely and effectively in order to mitigate actual and potential releases.  Lock out/Tag out procedures are in place to prevent further hazards around malfunctioning equipment or equipment being repaired.  Spill containment and cleanup procedures and training are in place to minimize the effects of a spill.

General employee training involves a knowledge of ammonia hazards, warning systems and evacuation procedures.

Annual corporate internal safety audits will include evaluations and recommendations for improving and updating the program.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Distribution Center has implemented the requirements of the Risk Management Plan in order to operate each facility in accordance with regulations and support of best industry standards and practices.  The ultimate objective is to minimize the risk of an accidental ammonia release.  The facility management has developed an Emergency Response Plan accompanied by appropriate training to ensure a fast and efficient response in the event of an accidental hazardous material release, fire or other emergency situation.  In order to prevent a potential accidental ammonia release the company has an ongoing review process for design and operating procedures. This assists in ensuring the refrigeration systems comply with OSHA, EPA and all other local, state and federal regulatory safety standards as well as Kroger's own internal safety and operational standards.

The Distribution Center has a rigorous emergency response training program that follows the guidelines of federal state and local regulatory agencies.  Management believes that cooperative emergency response training must include company employees, local emergency responders and regulators in order to provide a safe workplace and environment.  In an emergency all personnel are trained to cooperate with fellow employees and other support personnel as directed by the Emergency Response Incident Commander.

The Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center facility contains a refrigerated storage warehouse along with Dry Grocery and transportation services.  The large majority of products stored are food products intended for human consumption which pose no safety or environmental risks.  Anhydrous ammonia, a commonly used industrial refrigerant, is the refrigerant of choice for the cooling systems.  Ammonia refrigeration systems can be safely managed by properly trained operators.  The ammonia refrigeration system functions within a closed piping network serving facility operations.  The refrigeration system is predicted to contain a total of ~30,000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia.

In accordance with EPA Risk Management regulations accidental release scenarios have been proposed and modeled in order to forecast potential effects around and outside the facility.  The primary purpose of this modeling is to provide the Local Emergency Planning Commission with information which can be used in response planning and incidents.  It also is used for Emergency Response planning and training by facility response teams.  The release model used was the RMP Comp supplied by the EPA.

In the worst case scenario model the high pressure receiver ruptures and allowing discharge of the entire ammonia content in less than 10 minutes.  The potential radius of concern was forecast to be 1.8 miles.

The alternative, more likely, case modeled forecast a ruptured high pressure pipe which released for 45 minutes.  Based on the RMP Comp model the radius of toxic effect was .2 miles for this event.

The Kroger Co. is committed to the safe management and operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  Maintenance employees, the operators, are trained to operate the system using operating procedures designed to be as fail safe as possible in order to prevent accidental ammonia releases.  All maintenance employees are HAZWOPER trained technicians who will respond in the event of a release.  They are trained to act in cooperation with local responders and the LEPC to provide an effective response to any release.

The hazardous material release Prevention Program is built on the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard for ammonia refrigeration systems.  The PSM program has been implemented and covers the entire scope of operations from start-up to normal operations to shut downs and emergency response situations including clean-up and restoration to operation.  Normal operations rely on the following:

Maintenance Management Procedures and schedules are used to perform preventive maintenance, repairs and servicing of all system components.  Maintenance records of all work are maintained.  This ensures that the system continues to work safely reliably and efficiently in the intended manner.

Set critical specifications of system temperature, pressure, level or power supply are monitored and will alarm if safe operating parameters are exceeded or interrupted.  Critical exceedances, particularly level and pressure will result in system shutdowns.  Maintenance Technicians will be notified of such exceedances by alarms or alarm indicators.

In the event of deviations Maintenance Mechanics are trained, operating procedures are written and equipment available to safely analyze the deviation and respond appropriately with safety of the Mechanics, other employees and the public being the primary concern.

Lock-out/tag-out, Hot Work, Pump Down and Equipment Entry/Line Break procedures are in place to ensure that all Maintenance actions and equipment are suitable to the situation being addressed.  Equipment is to be isolated, locked out and taken out of service if unsafe to operate.

If a problem cannot be addressed by facility Maintenance personnel then procedures and necessary authorizations are in place to allow obtaining outside assistance.

Process Safety information required by the OSHA PSM standard  is in place which properly describes the system and allows effective evaluation and operation of the system.

Process Hazard Analyses of the systems have been accomplished using the What-If methodology.

Contractor Safety procedures are in place and have been implemented to ensure that contractors working on or around the refrigeration system are properly informed, trained and supervised.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE READINESS

Written Emergency Response Procedures include reporting, responder and agency notification, evacuation, emergency shutdown and response procedures.  They also include training requirements and expectations and recordkeeping procedures.

The Emergency Response Plan describes management of response operations.  It identifies Response Teams, assigns responsibilities and tasks to teams and team members and sets out procedures for communications, maintaining data and tracking information during a response.  Forms are provided for logging response activities.  Incident review and investigation procedures are in place to provide recommendations for improvements and prevention of recurrences.

The Emergency Response Training program includes all Maintenance employees and local emergency responders.  This allows coordination and familiarity with the systems and personnel involved.  All facility employees are trained in incident reporting and evacuation procedures.

It is the intent of Distribution Center management to not only meet any regulatory requirement but to also take a pro-active approach to implementing these requirements to incorporate these requirements into a working safety plan.  The Kroger Co. is in a constant reviewing process of its operations and industry standards in order to provide a safe working environment for our employees, customers and contractors and to avoid any harm to our community and the environment.

KROGER GREAT LAKES REGIONAL DISTRIBUTION CENTER SUMMARY

A.   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center recognizes management's responsibility in protecting its employees, the public, the environment, equipment and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the facility.

To accomplish the company's goal in preventing accidents, the facility has established a Facility Safety Program.  The objectives of the Safety Program are to: maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.

One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program is the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).  The facility Regulatory Compliance Manager is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.

The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs is to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs help prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses environmental impacts and physical property damage.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and

improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.

In addition to the Plant Safety Program, Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center follows these corporate safety guidelines. 

     Employee Handbook Plant Safety Rules
     Kroger Contractor Safety Rules
     Kroger Safety Inspection and Abatement Plans
     Safety Process Improvement Teams
  
B.   Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center is part of Kroger Dedicated Logistics Inc.  A portion of the facility is a refrigerated warehouse that stores perishable and frozen food products for assembly and distribution to retail outlets.  The facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system to provide cooling and freezing capabilities.  The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in the system is in excess of 10,000 pounds.  The maximum inventory in the system is predicted to be approximately 30,000 pounds.  Since an ammonia release from the system could pose a risk of offsite public and/or environmental impact and the system is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119), the system is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RMP program.

C.   Summary of Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

The worst-case release scenario at the Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center facility involves the release of ~17,500 pounds of ammonia over a 10 minute period due to the failure of the high pressure receiver (HPR-1).  This quantity represents the maximum quantity of ammonia in the receiver at any time.  Under worst-case weather conditions, ammonia could travel 1.8 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public. This distance has been calculated based on the method provided in EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR 68) Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration.

ion program consists of the following elements:

Employee Participation: This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing the program.  Employees are also to be involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted.  The program also ensures that all employees have complete access to the program.  Management responsibilities for the program have been assigned.

Process Safety Information: Written information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the system. The written information includes the ammonia MSDS and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration system.

Process Hazard Analysis: Formal studies using the What-If? technique have been conducted to examine the system and identify potential hazards. Any recommendations are resolved to improve facility safety. 

Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system.

Training: A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained on all aspects of the system and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.

Contractors: All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.

Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review is required  for all new ammonia projects to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use. They are also performed when there is a change in the  process safety information
    
Mechanical Integrity:  This program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration systems are built and maintained using preventive

maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.

Hot Work Permit: These procedures ensure that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning.

Management of Change: Procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration system are properly reviewed.

Incident Investigation: Procedures ensure that any incidents (and near misses) are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team. Any recommendations are resolved to improve the safety of the facility. 

Compliance Audits: There are procedures to conduct regular audits of the RM prevention program to ensure that the program is in place and working properly.  A tracking plan is included in the program to ensure that recommendations from audits are resolved. 

E.   Five-Year Accident History

There has been no ammonia-related incident at the Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center within the last five years - the facility has not yet been started.

F.   Description of the Emergency Response Program

An emergency response program has been implemented at the Great Lakes Regional Distribution Center facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  The Emergency Response Plan also addresses community notification and evacuation.  The program has been coordinated with the Delaware Fire Department and Delaware County LEPC.

The emergency response program consists of the following elements:

         Organization Plan and Responsibilities
         Communications Procedures
         Notification Procedures
         Response Action Plans
         First Aid Procedures
         Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
         Evacuation Plans
         Description of Outside Assistance Available
         Site Re-Entry Procedures
         Training Programs anrills
         Off Site Communications and Co-ordination with Government Agencies
